title: Chapter 1 - Introduction to Data Communication Model

questions.question: What are the main topics covered in the Introduction to Data Communication Model module?

options.text: Software Engineering, Circuit Analysis, and Programming Logic.
Data Communication Model, Data Communication, Networking, Protocols, and Protocol Architecture.
Cloud Computing, Database Management, and User Interface Design.
Signal Processing, Wireless Frequencies, and Satellite Orbit Mechanics.

questions.explanation: The main topics outlined in the course structure are the Introduction to Data Communication Model, Data Communication, Networking, Protocols, and Protocol Architecture.

questions.question: What are the specific learning outcomes for this chapter?

options.text: Write complex code for network security and configure firewalls.
Calculate the exact voltage requirements for transmission lines.
Explain networking details with technology/architecture and explain communication protocols.
Design a physical router chassis and solder motherboard components.

questions.explanation: The stated learning outcomes are to explain the Networking details with the technology and architecture, and to explain the communication protocols in Computer Networks.

questions.question: Which set of key terms are you expected to be able to use correctly after mastering this topic?

options.text: Networking, Entity, System, Protocol, Syntax, Semantics, PDU.
Broadband, WiFi, 5G, LTE, Fiber Optics, Bluetooth.
Router, Switch, Hub, Bridge, Gateway, Repeater.
Algorithm, Variable, Class, Object, Loop, Function.

questions.explanation: The key terms identified in the course that students must be able to use are Networking, Entity, System, Protocol, Syntax, Semantics, and PDU.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly lists the components of the Data Communications Model?

options.text: Input, Processing, Storage, Output, User.
Source, Router, Cloud, Firewall, Destination.
Sender, Message, Medium, Protocol, Feedback.
Source, Transmitter, Transmission System, Receiver, Destination.

questions.explanation: The Data Communications Model consists of the Source (generates data), Transmitter (converts data to signals), Transmission System (carries signals), Receiver (converts signals to data), and Destination (takes incoming data).

questions.question: Why is direct point-to-point communication often considered impractical for connecting many devices?

options.text: It requires devices to use incompatible operating systems.
Devices are too far apart and a large set of devices would require an impractical number of connections.
The data transfer speeds are significantly slower than wireless networks.
It consumes too much electrical power to maintain a single link.

questions.explanation: Point-to-point communication is not practical because devices are often too far apart, and connecting a large set of devices would require an impractical number of physical connections. The solution is a communications network.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a Wide Area Network (WAN)?

options.text: It covers a large geographical area and relies in part on common carrier circuits.
It is restricted to a single building or small campus environment.
It typically offers much higher data rates than Local Area Networks.
It is usually owned entirely by the same organization that owns the attached devices.

questions.explanation: WANs are characterized by covering a large geographical area, crossing public rights of way, relying on common carrier circuits, and utilizing technologies like circuit switching, packet switching, or frame relay.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a characteristic of a Local Area Network (LAN)?

options.text: It uses public rights of way to connect cities.
It relies heavily on circuit switching and common carrier circuits.
It has a smaller scope, is usually owned by one organization, and has high data rates.
It is designed primarily for low-speed communication over vast distances.

questions.explanation: LANs are characterized by a smaller scope (building or campus), are usually owned by the same organization as the devices, and have data rates much higher than WANs.

questions.question: In networking terminology, what is an 'Entity'?

options.text: The physical cable connecting two computers.
A distinct physical object like a computer or terminal.
The set of rules governing data exchange.
Anything capable of sending or receiving information, such as an application program.

questions.explanation: An Entity is defined as anything capable of sending or receiving information. Examples include application programs, file transfer packages, and email packages.

questions.question: In networking terminology, what is a 'System'?

options.text: A specialized software for error detection.
A physically distinct object that contains one or more entities.
The timing mechanism used to synchronize signals.
A specific format for data headers.

questions.explanation: A System is a physically distinct object that contains one or more entities. Examples include computers, terminals, and remote sensors.

questions.question: What three things must two entities agree on to communicate successfully?

options.text: What is communicated, How it is communicated, and When it is communicated.
Who is the sender, Who is the receiver, and Who is the administrator.
The brand of hardware, the operating system, and the power source.
The password, the encryption key, and the user ID.

questions.explanation: For successful communication, entities must agree on what is communicated, how it is communicated, and when it is communicated. This agreement is established through protocols.

questions.question: What are the key elements of a protocol?

options.text: Hardware, Software, and Firmware.
Input, Processing, and Output.
Syntax, Semantics, and Timing.
Packets, Frames, and Bits.

questions.explanation: The key elements of protocols are Syntax (data formats/signal levels), Semantics (control info/error handling), and Timing (speed matching/sequencing).

questions.question: How are communication tasks typically structured in protocol architecture (e.g., for file transfer)?

options.text: They are combined into a single monolithic program.
They are broken up into modules, such as file transfer, communication service, and network access.
They are handled entirely by the hardware without software modules.
They are distributed randomly across different network nodes.

questions.explanation: Communication tasks are broken up into modules. For example, a file transfer might use a File Transfer Application module, a Communication Service module, and a Network Access module.

questions.question: What are the two levels of addressing requirements in communication architecture?

options.text: Email address and website URL.
Physical address and GPS coordinates.
Admin password and user password.
A unique network address for the computer and a unique address (SAP) for the application.

questions.explanation: The architecture requires two levels of addressing: each computer needs a unique network address, and each application on a multitasking computer needs a unique address, known as a Service Access Point (SAP).

questions.question: What is a Protocol Data Unit (PDU)?

options.text: User data plus control information added at each layer.
The physical cable used to transmit the signal.
The raw binary stream without any headers or formatting.
The software license required to use the network.

questions.explanation: A Protocol Data Unit (PDU) consists of the user data along with the control information (header) added at a specific layer of the protocol architecture.

questions.question: Which items are typically found in a Transport PDU?

options.text: Voltage levels, pin configurations, and cable type.
Router IP address, subnet mask, and gateway.
Destination SAP, sequence number, and error detection code.
User password, file name, and file size only.

questions.explanation: A Transport layer PDU typically includes the destination Service Access Point (SAP), a sequence number for ordering, and an error detection code.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a principle of the OSI Reference Model?

options.text: All layers must function simultaneously using the same hardware.
Each layer performs a subset of functions and relies on the next lower layer.
Changes in one layer require rewriting the code for all other layers.
Higher layers provide services to the lower layers.

questions.explanation: The OSI model is a layered model where each layer performs a subset of functions, relies on the lower layer for primitive functions, provides services to the higher layer, and allows changes in one layer without affecting others.

questions.question: Which list correctly identifies the layers of the OSI Reference Model?

options.text: Input, Processing, Storage, Output, Feedback, Control, User.
Network Access, Internet, Transport, Application.
Source, Transmitter, System, Receiver, Destination, Signal, Data.
Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, Physical.

questions.explanation: The 7 layers of the OSI Reference Model are: Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, and Physical.

questions.question: What is the origin of the TCP/IP Protocol Suite?

options.text: It was developed by US DoD research and specified before the OSI model.
It was created by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO).
It was developed specifically for internal use in local area networks only.
It was a commercial product released by Microsoft in the 1990s.

questions.explanation: The TCP/IP Protocol Suite was developed by research funded by the US Department of Defense, was specified before the OSI model, and became the dominant commercial architecture used by the Internet.

questions.question: What are the layers of the TCP/IP Protocol Suite?

options.text: Application, Session, Presentation, Transport.
Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session.
Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access/Physical.
Start, Link, Path, End.

questions.explanation: The TCP/IP Protocol Suite consists of the Application Layer, Transport Layer (TCP/UDP), Internet Layer (IP), and the Network Access/Physical Layer.

questions.question: What is the function of the Application Layer in the TCP/IP suite?

options.text: It manages the voltage and signal encoding on the wire.
It handles communication between processes or applications.
It routes data packets across different networks.
It provides error detection for the physical medium.

questions.explanation: In the TCP/IP suite, the Application Layer is responsible for communication between processes or applications.

questions.question: What is the function of the Transport Layer in the TCP/IP suite?

options.text: It facilitates end-to-end transfer of data and may include reliability mechanisms.
It defines the mechanical and electrical specifications of the interface.
It determines the best path for data to travel across the internet.
It directly converts digital data into analog signals.

questions.explanation: The Transport Layer (e.g., TCP) handles end-to-end transfer of data, hides the details of the underlying network, and may include reliability mechanisms.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the Internet Layer (IP) in the TCP/IP suite?

options.text: It provides the user interface for applications.
It manages the physical connection to the cable.
It handles the sequencing of data packets for applications.
It handles the routing of data.

questions.explanation: The Internet Layer (IP) is responsible for the routing of data across the network.

questions.question: What does the Network Access Layer in the TCP/IP suite do?

options.text: It provides the logical interface between the end system and the network.
It manages the dialogue and synchronization between applications.
It ensures that data is encrypted for secure transmission.
It is responsible for the high-level logic of the application software.

questions.explanation: The Network Access Layer provides the logical interface between the end system and the network, and it handles physical aspects such as the transmission medium, signal rate, and encoding.
